description:
Microsporum canis is a filamentous fungus that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a dermatophyte, a group of fungi that can infect the skin, hair, and nails of humans and animals.

Microsporum canis CBS 113480 is a specific strain or isolate of the species, with the CBS (Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures) number 113480 indicating its registration in the CBS culture collection.

The fungus typically grows as a mold, producing septate hyphae and numerous asexual spores called macroconidia. These macroconidia have a distinctive fusiform (spindle-shaped) appearance and are considered a key diagnostic feature of the species.

Microsporum canis is a common causative agent of ringworm (dermatophytosis) in domestic animals, especially cats and dogs, and can also infect humans, particularly children. Infection by this fungus can lead to circular, scaling skin lesions and hair loss in affected individuals.
